hyperlocal_site.description: EastLondonLines is an independent news website produced by students and staff of Goldsmiths, University of London. It will be the virtual shadow of the new East London Line, connecting communities in virtual space, just as the new line connects them in physical space. For the first time the residents of Croydon can easily access the bars of Shoreditch, and a single Mum in Hackney can reasonably contemplate a job in Crystal Palace. Goldsmiths college lies in the centre of the line and students on our world-class journalism courses will be keeping you informed about your newly connected world. Their work will be guided by experienced journalists, and it is our hope that EastLondonLines will in time, provide not only a place to learn, but a place to earn, for young journalists entering a profession currently beset by problems. We promise to bring you real news, produced to the highest ethical standards, but we will also tell you about the people and the pleasures to be found along the line.

hyperlocal_site.title: Energy Royd
hyperlocal_site.description:
Energy Royd is a public service, social media website about energy and climate change issues for the Upper Calder Valley. A grant from UnLtd enabled its set up in its current beta version.

It currently carries four main types of posts:  

 
-aggregated international and national energy and climate change news
-introductory information and opinion pieces on energy and climate change issues
-local energy and climate change news stories and information
-listings of local energy and climate change activities, events, opportunities

I am working on moving the website on from its beta stage. The aims are to:

-link Energy Royd into a new, hyper-local citizen media project
-work with the Calderdale NUJ Branch and local Johnston Press to identify how community-sourced material can be generated to decent journalistic standards and reward its creators appropriately, without threatening professional journalists’ jobs and incomes
-create and screen an ongoing online drama that relates closely to the news and views content of Energy Royd
-link Energy Royd into local action for environmental and social justice

hyperlocal_site.title: Finchlinks
hyperlocal_site.description:
Finchlinks is a website for anyone who lives in Finchley in North London. Narrowing it down a bit, we mostly cover the bits of Finchley to the North of the A406 (North Circular) mainly because thereâ€™s a busy community site serving East Finchley already, alongside a commercial one.

Weâ€™re here to encourage positive local community projects that involve voluntary co-operation. Weâ€™re expressly not a local political website and we donâ€™t take sides â€“ weâ€™ll cover or link to anything that we think is of interest.

We want to set up some LinkedIn groups to promote local business networking (any volunteers for this?). There is already a Facebook group for Finchley Village, and weâ€™ve got one for North Finchley and Woodside Park as well. And weâ€™re on twitter at @finchlinks

We will be concentrating on the bits of Finchley north of the A406 â€“ North, West and Central Finchley. There is already a lively community site for East Finchley â€“ here. Thereâ€™s also a wider community site for the whole of The London Borough of Barnet.

This site is here to help develop a community of people in the area who are talking to each other a bit more. We want to use it to promote good innovative ideas and to help people who want to do interesting things in the area to meet up with each other. An early post on the site have covered a lot of this in more detail.

Weâ€™d like to start informal business meetups and get people together for arts / culture / history / educational projects. Weâ€™re looking for people with positive ideas (and when we set the site up, we had a few of our own â€“ stay tuned) to get a discussion going.

Weâ€™re not a political project and we donâ€™t want to nail our colours to any particular approach to local regeneration. Instead, we want to help you to get together with others to describe the challenges that you think the area faces. Weâ€™re asking commenters to be as positive as they can.

hyperlocal_site.title: Friends of Moseley Road Baths
hyperlocal_site.description:
Moseley Road Pool is not a museum, it is a working building. It houses two attractive swimming pools, only one of which is still in operation. The larger pool closed in October 2003 due to a leak and structural problems with the spectatorâ€™s balcony. The other pool is used by people of all ages, backgrounds, capabilities and needs. Until 2004 Moseley Road Baths operated the only public washing baths in the city.

Although not presently operating at full capacity, many people from the surrounding area as well as nationally, recognise the importance of Moseley Road Baths, this Grade II* listed building, and have campaigned over a number of years to keep this beautiful yet pragmatic building open for a wide range of people to use and enjoy.

As it struggles to meet the demand for swimming and to accommodate the needs of people with a whole range of swimming needs it is clear how essential it is to invest in this national treasure.

hyperlocal_site.description:
Transforming an area of derelict land into a well designed, user friendly green open space in which people can enjoy, relax in and possibly take part in a range of acitivies. It was named Green Heart Den by local school children. 

We are also hoping to gain approval to: i) develop several adjacent, vacant railway arches in such a way that will be of benefit to the community. ii) are currently in the progress of developing a similar piece of land, to the immediate north of the railway arches, into a community "grow your own" type scheme. It is hoped that the full involvement of local people in the process will not only provide the best opportunity for long term sustainability of the project but will also help with the wider social and economic regeneration of the area, providing people with skills and confidence to start new projects, access training or further education or find employment either within the project or elsewhere.

hyperlocal_site.title: Loch of Shining Waters
hyperlocal_site.description:
Loch of Shining Waters is a non-profit voluntary group which was officially launched on the 1st January 2010 as a community resource site for Lochgelly, with the aim to highlight local positive and negative developments to (a) raise awareness to the wider online public, and (b) encourage local open debate online.

The name of the group is derived from the Gelly Loch, which gives the namesake of our town. The word Gelly is from a Gaelic word; ‘Gheallaidh’ which loosely translated means ‘Shining Waters’ or ‘Loch of Brightness’, hence the name ‘Loch of Shining Waters’ for our group. We chose this name to mark the significance of our local Loch and the towns namesake.

The site was created by two volunteers from the Lochgelly area, who have spent many hours researching, networking and engaging with many local individuals, groups, and the local authority to help further develop this resource site for the benefit of the local community.

The site has grown in popularity and content since 2010, and we have received much help from the local community through feedback, support and contributions, which has led to many awards for the work that we all do collectively.

On the 17th November 2012, the group has formalised the organisation by signing a constitution and selecting a board of members. Currently we are a constituted voluntary group, but aim to develop the project into a Social Enterprise or Registered Charity so we can better serve the local community.

The reason we have opted for a constitution, is so that we can further develop the project to develop local projects and initiatives through community engagement, to provide additional community resources directly in the Lochgelly area, and expand our community services beyond an online role.

hyperlocal_site.title: Manchester MULE
hyperlocal_site.description:
MULE is a Manchester based non-profit independent media project, looking to promote social justice by getting out the news and views you wonâ€™t find elsewhere, from the rainy city and beyond!

To this end, we produce a quarterly newspaper with a print run of 10,000 copies, distributed free around Manchester. Our website is updated regularly with news, culture, opinion and features on events in the Greater Manchester region.

The Thinking behind MULE

Three core principles underlie our work:

1) Providing an alternative has never been more important. Traditional local media is facing hard times. Budget cuts and the turn away from serious reporting means thereâ€™s an information vacuum waiting to be filled in our communities. On a wider level, the commercial media system is dominated by a small number of huge corporations and wealthy individuals. This system promotes commercial values, and filters out information not conducive to the immediate bottom line or long-run corporate interests. MULE aims to cover the burning issues that the mainstream media neglect, without screaming down peoples necks, being boring or preachy, or speaking to a select, in-the-know audience.

2) Media as a tool for social change. At its best independent media supports progressive social movements by raising public awareness and providing information that is a tool in the hands of campaigners. This starts at home. The place we can be most effective is in our backyard, holding power to account in Manchester.

3) Openness and inclusivity. From the start, MULE has been an organisation run primarily by volunteers. We want to provide an opportunity for writers, designers, web geeks and volunteers of all varieties, to get involved and share or improve their skills.

hyperlocal_site.title: myhandsworth
hyperlocal_site.description:
MyHandsworth is an independent blog for the Handsworth community. The aim of this initiative is to facilitate coverage of news, events, civic campaigns and to celebrate the accomplishments of the residents in their various pursuits. The website is published Sihlangu Tshuma an Online Journalism Postgraduate student at Birmingham City University.

The website has been necessitated by the lack of progressive reporting about Handsworth in the mainstream media. Although the area has endured a difficult history, there have been significant achievements which need to be documented and publicised. Handsworth is a vibrant multi-cultural community, which makes it a reporter’s paradise.

The principal aim of the website is to promote civic pride. The website will encourage debate and action on different civic matters. The residents will be able to use it for campaigning and registering matters that need to be addressed by the local authorities such as the Birmingham City Council.

hyperlocal_site.title: RoathCardiff
hyperlocal_site.description:
ABOUT
CONTACT
ROATH PEOPLE
SOCIAL MEDIA SURGERY
4AM PROJECT
About
The Roath Cardiff site is a place for local news, views and events from this wonderful area of the Welsh capital.

We will be sharing when Roath makes the news, what residents of Roath are up to and interesting events going on in and around the area. We’ll also have some local history and nice pictures for good measure.

If you’ve got something you’d like to see on the site just get in touch and we’ll do our best to feature it.

We’re also closely linked with the Roath Cardiff twitter feed, which pumps out a vast amount of information about the local area and what people are up to. We suggest following it for updates.

Who is behind the site?

There’s a team of three of us. We do it because we’re interested in the local area. We are Matt Appleby, Geraldine Nichols and Huw Thomas. We have to give a big thank you to Ed Walker (formerly of yourcardiff) who was on the original team before moving up to London.

When did it start?

It started in June 2011 after a chat in the Albany pub.

Can I get something featured?

Sure, just drop us a line. We’re all ears to anything Roath related.

hyperlocal_site.description:
In the midst of life I woke to find myself living in an old house beside Brick Lane in the East End of London. Over the coming days, weeks, months and years, I am going to write every single day and tell you about my life here in Spitalfields at the heart of London. How can I ever describe the exuberant richness and multiplicity of culture in this place to you?  This is both my task and my delight.

Let me disclose to you the hare-brained ambition I am pursuing, which is to write at least ten thousand posts about Spitalfields life. At the rate of one a day, this will take approximately twenty-seven years and four months.

hyperlocal_site.title: The Soho Times
hyperlocal_site.description:
The Community Newspaper for the Soho Road, Handsworth and Dudley Road Communities.

Whether you've lived here for 50 years or just arrived from another part of the country or another part of the world you've got to admit the neighbourhoods that make up the Soho Road, Handsworth and Dudley Road communities are diverse and vibrant. It's not perfect and changes need to be made but how do you make sure your voice is heard amongst all the other noise going on? How do you help make a difference to your community and link with others who want to do the same? Welcome to The Soho Times - the community newspaper for the community by the community.

Do - These are the amazing stories about your neighbourhood that we want to share, celebrate and tell the world about. What makes you proud about your neighbourhood? Are there places that are especially important to you? Do you or someone you know do something in the community that would inspire others?

Dream - What are your dreams for your neighbourhood? What would you change or add to make it better? Share you ideas. Your neighbours might want the same dreams to happen.

Pledge - How could we work together to make our dreams for the neighbourhood happen? Make a promise to take action here. The more people that pledge to an idea the more likely it is to take place.

hyperlocal_site.title: Visit Scunthorpe
hyperlocal_site.description:
VisitScunthorpe.Com started life in 2009 as my personal blog. I did not like wordpress as it was very one sided, I wrote, reader's commented.

I wanted a web site that the whole community could participate in as equals, and discuss issues of local concern / import, so I decided to develop my own blogging tools.

Visit Scunthorpe deals with all local issues, local politics and a few national events which affect Scunthorpe very directly. It's a free site and I actively encourage any one in the North Lincolnshire Area to sign up and start telling us what's going on.

I've also added photo galleries and a highly searchable database with all the local councillors, contact details and responsibilities in it
